report_title: Foot Care Product Manufacturing Industry Report
executive_summary: The Foot Care Product Manufacturing industry is characterized by a diverse, fragmented set of companies producing a wide range of products intended for the treatment or prevention of foot conditions. The broad variety of products manufactured by this industry insulates the industry from shifts in demand for any particular product line, while the medically necessary nature of many of its products keeps overall relatively demand steady. The industry has contended with increased import penetration over the five years to 2021, in addition to the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic, leading the industry to contract. As a result, industry revenue is expected to fall during the current period, decreasing at an annualized rate of 2.2% to $633.2 million. However, due to increasing demand for industry exports, combined with a domestic recovery in healthcare utilization and consumer spending, industry revenue is forecast to grow 1.5% in 2021 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The Foot Care Product Manufacturing industry is characterized by a high degree of competition among a broad range of large and small producers manufacturing a wide variety of foot care products.

The sheer variety of products offered by this industry insulates foot care product manufacturers' revenue from excessive volatility, and the medically necessary nature of many industry goods also helps to contain overall volatility.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Negative impact from imports and pandemic
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Over the five years to 2021, two principal threats have negatively affected the industry: increased import penetration has resulted in a loss of market share for many operators, while the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic upended daily life in 2020 and caused a global recession.
As a result, revenue is expected to decline during the current period, falling at an annualized rate of 2.2% to $633.2 million in 2021.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Over the five years to 2026, competition from foreign operators is expected to diminish somewhat as domestic operators increasingly export their products to foreign markets and the share of domestic demand satisfied by imports stabilizes.
A continued global economic recovery from the coronavirus pandemic will likely benefit industry operators for both domestic sales and exports.
However, a possible strengthening of the dollar would threaten industry operators' growth prospects, subjecting the industry's trade outlook to some uncertainty.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Revenue growth expected during outlook period
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: During the outlook period, IBISWorld expects industry revenue to grow at an annualized rate of 1.2% to $673.0 million.

industry_definition: Companies in this industry are engaged in manufacturing medicated and nonmedicated preparations, bandages and other treatments for the prevention and treatment of foot care conditions including dry skin, athlete's foot, fallen arches, blisters, corns, calluses and bunions. This industry does not include manufacturers of professional medical-surgical orthopedic products, orthopedic shoes or products intended primarily as cosmetics (e.g. nail polish).

key_trends: Foot issues can occur for a wide variety of reasons, and demographic trends in the United States have contributed to their prevalence
As a result of industry contraction, profit has also declined over the past five years

The continued expansion of healthcare coverage will likely keep demand and consumers' ability to pay for industry products high

market_segmentation.segment_description: The Foot Care Product Manufacturing industry is expected to generate 29.6% of its revenue from exports in 2021, up slightly from 26.5% in 2016.
Online retailers of foot care products, such as Dr. Todd's, have grown over the past five years as consumers have increased their online purchases of many types of products.

Health stores and foot care specialty stores tend to have an even larger selection of industry products than pharmacies and drug stores, which attracts customers with niche or particularly severe foot problems.

In 2021, mass merchandisers and supermarkets account for an estimated 13.3% of industry revenue. This market segment's share of revenue has declined over the past five years due to faster growth in demand from other downstream markets.
Pharmacies and drug stores are expected to generate 10.7% of industry revenue in 2021.
Wholesalers, while losing market share over the past five years, are expected to account for 6.8% of industry revenue in 2021.
Podiatrists and other doctors purchase industry products to treat their patients with or to sell to their patients.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Wart, fungus and other medical foot creams and lotions
products_and_services.product_description: Wart, fungus and other medical foot creams and lotions are manufactured with the purpose of treating a variety of foot disorders, most commonly athlete's foot and other fungal diseases.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Moisturizing and drying creams and powders
products_and_services.product_description: Moisturizing and drying creams and powders are not designed to treat specific foot disorders or diseases, but to reduce foot moisture, prevent unpleasant foot odor and increase foot softness.
Insoles and heel lifts generate an estimated 15.6% of industry revenue in 2021.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Sleeves, Braces, Adhesive Pads and Other Related Products
products_and_services.product_description: This product segment includes a wide variety of pads, braces and other light-weight devices used to treat bunions, corns, warts and other foot problems.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Pumice Stones and Other Foot Filers
products_and_services.product_description: Pumice stones and other foot filers are used to file down calluses and corns for both aesthetic and comfort purposes.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: While many industry products are largely cosmetic in nature, others also have clearly defined medical purposes. For example, bunion sleeves, moleskin pads and wart creams are all purchased with the intention of treating medical foot conditions. As visits to podiatrists increase, they tend to purchase more industry products to give to or treat their patients. Increased spending on healthcare products, including those produced by the Foot Care Product Manufacturing industry, also increases industry demand.

Moreover, older adults are more likely to experience health problems and are therefore more likely to spend money on healthcare, including spending on foot health issues. As a result, the average age of the US population also has an effect on industry demand. The prevalence of individuals with diabetes also tends to increase demand for industry products because diabetes can cause foot related health issues, such as neuropathy. Similarly, the prevalence of fungal infections and other foot-related medical complications tends to drive demand for industry products.
Demand for industry products is also affected by the quality, price and availability of foreign imports. Imports are estimated to account for over half of domestic demand in 2021.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Due to the relative simplicity of many industry products, such as pumice stones and rubber shoe insoles, a large and growing share of the domestic market for foot care products is satisfied through imports from countries with low wage costs.

Foreign demand for popular US brands is relatively high due to the high quality and brand recognition of products produced by domestic manufacturers. However, demand for US exports has stagnated over the five years to 2021 due to two factors; prior to 2020, a strong US dollar and increasing competition from foreign producers reduced demand for US-manufactured foot care products on international markets, leading export levels to decline; subsequently, in 2020, the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic devastated the global economy and therefore demand from foreign countries.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region has the highest number of establishments.
The West has a wealthy population with a relatively high concentration of podiatrists.
The Great Lakes region accounts for 16.2% of industry establishments.

regulations_points.regulation_description: New industry products that are classified as having a medical application are required to undergo FDA testing procedures for over-the-counter (OTC) medications prior to being brought onto the market.
The FDA also tests and regulates cosmetic, nonmedical, industry products to ensure that they are safe for consumer use.
Amid the coronavirus pandemic in 2020, many consumers adapted to remote work conditions, changing their commuting, exercise and lifestyle routines, altering demand for footcare products.

barriers_points.barrier_title: Low capital requirements for small-scale manufacturers
barriers_points.barrier_description: Start-up expenses for a small-scale foot moisturizer manufacturer are low. Moisturizer manufactures only require basic equipment and facilities.

basis_points.basis_description: Companies primarily compete on price, product quality and consumer preferences. Low production costs, wide product variety and limited regulation enable low market share concentration.
Industry faces significant competition from low-cost imports like China and Malaysia for inexpensive products, and high-quality imports from Europe for luxury products.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The industry produces diverse products like moisturizers, antifungal creams, insoles made by many companies.
The three largest companies expected to account for less than 10% of industry revenue in 2021.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Industry profit, measured as earnings before interest and taxes, is expected to account for 5.1% of revenue for the Foot Care Product Manufacturing industry in 2021.
Wages account for an estimated 19.7% of industry revenue in 2021.
Purchase expenses are expected to account for 31.9% of industry revenue in 2021.
Depreciation accounts for an estimated 1.6% of industry revenue in 2021.
Marketing accounts for an estimated 0.4% of industry revenue in 2021.
Rental costs account for an estimated 0.7% of industry revenue in 2021.
Spending on utilities accounts for an estimated 0.5% of industry revenue in 2021.
Other costs are estimated to account for the remaining 39.8% of industry revenue in 2021.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The Foot Care Product Manufacturing industry has a low level of capital intensity, measured as the ratio of depreciation, as a smoothed measure of capital expenditures, to industry labor costs.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Revenue volatility for the Foot Care Product Manufacturing industry is moderate.
The growing incidence of diabetes has increased demand for foot care products in recent years.
The COVID-19 pandemic in 2020 contributed to revenue volatility.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The Foot Care Product Manufacturing industry has been resilient to technological disruption.
The production of most industry products involves a low level of complexity.
